title: How to Know if You're Getting a Fair Pokémon Card Trade

steps.headline: Make sure that you trust the person that you’re trading with.
steps.description: This itself can save you from making an unfair trade. If you know the person well enough to know that they’ll not trick you into making an unfair trade, you're in a good spot to trade with them.

steps.headline: Look at the number of cards that are part of the trade.
steps.description: See how many cards your trading partner and yourself are trading away. If you’re trading away more Pokémon cards than your trading partner, then it may be an unfair trade. The exception is if you want a very strong Pokémon that your trading partner has. If you want to trade away two or three weaker Pokémon for a strong one, then that’s okay. Be cautious and careful about this decision.

steps.headline: Look at the HP of the Pokémon you are trading.
steps.description: The HP represents your Pokémon’s health points, which also represents how strong they are. The HP of a Pokémon is located at the top-right of the Pokémon cards. See if the HP of both your card and your trading partner's Pokémon differ a lot, of not. If you and your trading partner's Pokémon’s HP are really unequal, it’s likely an unfair trade. If it’s off by just a hair, that’s okay.

steps.headline: Look at the attack moves.
steps.description: Pokémons' attack move’s damage can differ from one another; some are stronger than others. See what attack moves you and your trading partner's Pokémon cards have, and determine whether it is a fair trade or not; you don’t want to trade away a Pokémon that’s stronger than the one you are trading for.

steps.headline: Look at the Pokémon stages.
steps.description: The stages your Pokémon can be are Basic, Stage One (Evolution Card), and Stage Two (Evolution Card). A stage of a Pokémon can determines how strong a Pokémon is; Stage Twos are the strongest state and Basics are the weakest stage. If you’re trading a Stage for anything way weaker or higher, that is potentially an unfair trade.

steps.headline: Make sure the cards are not fake.
steps.description: Sometimes, people trick you into trading a card for a fake card. You can tell if the card they’re trading away is fake by looking at the back. The back should be dark blue. Most fake cards have light blue on the back. You can also check the images on the card. If the image on the card seems uneven, then it is fake. You can also compare your cards with the fake one (try to compare them to the same cards). If the card you are comparing looks completely different from yours, there is no doubt that it is a fake.

steps.headline: Be sure you really want the card you’re trading for.
steps.description: Don’t act too rashly; it may lead you to make a very bad trade. Take your time. If the person you’re trading with seems to pressuring you into making a trade, or rushing you to hurry up, those are signs they may not be making a fair trade.
